front.title: What is Scrum
front.content: What is the general definition of Scrum

back.title: Scrum is a lightweight framework
back.content: It helps people, teams and organisations generate value through adaptive solutions for complex problems

front.title: Scrum in a nutshell
front.content: What environment is a scrum master expected to foster?

back.title: An adaptive environment
back.content: Product Owner orders the work in a product backlog; Scrum team turns the selection of work into an Increment value during a sprint, Scrum team and stakeholders inspect the results and adjust for next sprint

back.title: Collective Intelligence of the people
back.content: Scrum is an adaptive, iterative framework that builds upon the collective intelligence of the people using it. It does not provide detailed instructions, rather it provides users with a guide for relationships and interactions

front.title: What is Scrum founded on?
front.content: What is the key foundation to which Scrum is founded

back.title: Empiricism and Lean Thinking
back.content: Empiricism asserts that knowledge comes from experience, and decisions are made based on what is observed. Lean thinking focuses on reducing waste and only focusing on the essentials

front.title: What techniques does Scrum employ?
front.content: How does scrum optimise predictability and control risk?

back.title: Use Iterative, incremental approach
back.content: Scrum engages groups of people who collectively have all the skills and expertise to do the work; or can acquire such skills as needed

front.title: Formal Events in Scrum
front.content: How many formal events are in scrum?

back.title: There are 5 events in Scrum
back.content: The Sprint itself, Sprint planning, Daily Scrum, Sprint Review and Sprint Retrospective. These are the only 5 events that exist for scrum

front.title: Scrum Pillars
front.content: What are the Scrum pillars?

back.title: There are 3 pillars to Scrum
back.content: Transparency - visible to everyone involved, Inspection - inspect and review to ensure progress is towards agreed goals, and Adaption - when there is deviation from the agreed goals

front.title: Transparency
front.content: What is Transparency?

back.title: Visible to everyone involved
back.content: Emergent process and work must be visible to those performing in and those receiving it. Important decisions are based on the perceived state of the Three Formal Artifacts. Without transparency, the decisions made might diminish in value and increase risk of bad results

front.title: Inspection
front.content: What is Inspection?

back.title: Inspect and Review Progress
back.content: Transparency enables Inspection. Purpose is to review the progress and ensure its heading towards agreed goals. Inspect frequently and diligently to detect potential undesirable variances/problems. Scrum provides cadence in the form of 5 events

front.title: Adaption
front.content: What is Adaption?

back.title: Change in plan when deviation are detected
back.content: Adapt if inspection finds issues. If process deviates outside acceptable limits resulting product may not meet established goals. Adjustments to the plan must be made as soon as possible to minimise further deviation. Adaption works only if teams are empowered and self-managing.

front.title: Scrum Values
front.content: What are the Scrum values

back.title: There are 5 (FORCC)
back.content: Focus, Openness, Respect, Courage, and Commitment. COMMIT to achieve its goals and support each other. FOCUS is to make the best possible progress towards goals. OPEN to discuss work and challenges. RESPECT each other to be capable. COURAGE to do the right thing

front.title: Purpose of Scrum Values
front.content: Why are Scrum values important?

back.title: Give Direction to Scrum Team
back.content: The values give direction to the team regarding their WORK, ACTIONS, and BEHAVIOURS. Decisions made, steps taken, how scrum is used should reinforce, not diminish values. Applied when working with scrum EVENTS and ARTIFACTS. Combined with Pillars to build trust

front.title: Scrum Team
front.content: Who are part of the Scrum Team

back.title: Dev team, Product Owner, Scrum Master
back.content: 1 PO, 1 SM, and the Development Team. No sub teams or hierarchies. Cohesive unit of professionals focused on the PRODUCT GOAL. Cross-functional (have all the skills necessary to create value for each sprint). Self-managing (decide what when and how).

front.title: Scrum Team Size
front.content: How big should a scrum team be?

back.title: No more than 11 people
back.content: Small teams are nimble and large enough to complete significant work. 3-9 Devs, 1 SM, 1 PO. This is because of communication efficiencies. Too large, reorg into multiple scrum team focused on the same product, with same Product Goal, Backlog and PO.

front.title: Scrum Team Responsibilities
front.content: What are the responsibilities of the Scrum team?

back.title: All product related activities
back.content: Stakeholder collaboration, verification, maintenance, ops, experiment, R&D, etc. Empowered by the organisation to manage their own work. Working in sprints at a SUSTAINABLE pace that improves focus and consistency

front.title: Scrum Accountability
front.content: What is the Scrum team accountable for?

back.title: Creating valuable useful increment
back.content: Scrum defines three accountabilities and three roles; the development team, the product owner, and the scrum master

front.title: Development Team
front.content: What is the Dev team responsible for?

back.title: Creating a useable increment each sprint
back.content: Creating the Sprint Backlog, Adhering to Definition of Done, Adapting the plan toward the Sprint goal, holding each other ACCOUNTABLE as professionals. The goal of the sprint is to create a useable, quality increment that can be released to production

front.title: Product Owner
front.content: What is the Product Owner responsible for?

back.title: Maximising value produced by the Scrum Team
back.content: Develop and communicate CLEARLY: product goal, product backlog items (PBI). Ordering PBI, ensuring Product backlog is transparent, visible, understood. PO may delegate, but ultimately accountable. PO must be one person who represents needs of the stakeholder

front.title: Purpose of the Product Backlog
front.content: What is the purpose of the Product Backlog

back.title: Represent the needs of the stakeholders
back.content: The Product Backlog, its content and ordering represent the decisions of the Product owner. Order defines what order the items will be created (through the sprint and delivered increment). The whole backlog represent the needs of the stakeholders

front.title: Scrum Master
front.content: What is the Scrum Master responsible for?

back.title: Scrum Team Effectiveness
back.content: SM establishes scrum and teaches and facilitates. Ultimately responsible for the teams effectiveness. Includes Coaching, help team focus on creating high value increments and definition of done, remove impediments, ensure scrum EVENTS take place and productive within timebox

front.title: Scrum Master to PO
front.content: How does the SM service the PO?

back.title: PB management, product planning, stakeholder collab
back.content: Find techniques for effective product goal and PB management; Help scrum team understand PBI; establish empirical product planning; help facilitate stakeholder collab (when needed)

front.title: Scrum Master to Org
front.content: How does a Scrum master service the Org?

back.title: Champion Scrum adoption, remove barriers
back.content: Lead, train, coach on Scrum adoption; plan, advise Scum implementation; Help employees and stakeholders understand and enact empirical approach; and remove barriers between stakeholders and Scrum Teams

front.title: Scrum Events
front.content: What are the Scrum Events?

back.title: There are 5 events in Scrum
back.content: The Sprint (container for all events); Each event is a formal opportunity to INSPECT and ADAPT artifacts. Designed to enable transparency. Failure to operate any events results in lost opportunities to inspect and adapt.

front.title: Scrum Events Purpose
front.content: What are the purpose of Scrum Events?

back.title: Create Regularity, Reduce meetings, reduce complexity
back.content: Events are used to create regularity and minimise the need for meetings not defined in Scrum. All events should be held at the same time and place to REDUCE COMPLEXITY

front.title: The Sprint
front.content: What is a Sprint?

back.title: Fixed length events, a container for all other events
back.content: One month or less (consistency). New Sprint starts IMMEDIATELY after the previous sprint. All other events to achieve Product Goals happen within a sprint.

front.title: Sprint activities
front.content: Rules of a Sprint

back.title: Key points happen during a Sprint
back.content: No changes are made that endangers the SPRINT GOAL; quality does not decrease; Product Backlog is refined; Scope clarified and renegotiated with PO

front.title: Sprint Purpose
front.content: What is sprint duration and what does it enable?

back.title: Enable Predictability, reduce risk and costs
back.content: Predictability by ensuring INSPECTION and ADAPTION toward product goal (every calendar month). Too long, the goal may be invalid, rise in complexity, risks may increase. Short sprints to generate more learning cycles, limit risk of cost and effort. Each sprint can be considered a short project

front.title: Ideal Sprint Length
front.content: What is the Ideal Sprint Length

back.title: No more than 1 month
back.content: 1 - 4 weeks, no more than 4 weeks per sprint. Duration of Sprint must not change during the sprint. Duration can be changed during retro by PO, but should not be done too frequently (consistency)

front.title: Cancelling a Sprint
front.content: When can a Sprint be cancelled and by whom?

back.title: Only PO has authority to cancel (not even CEO)
back.content: Cancelled if the sprint goal becomes obsolete. And Only the PO can cancel the sprint

front.title: Sprint Planning
front.content: What is Sprint planning?

back.title: Initiates sprint by laying out work performed
back.content: Collaborative plan by the entire scrum team. PO ensures only most important PBI are discussed and how they map to Product Goal. Scrum team may invite others to attend to provide ADVICE (e.g. technical)

front.title: Sprint Planning Topics
front.content: What are the topics in Sprint Planning?

back.title: Why, What, How
back.content: Why is this sprint valuable; What can be DONE in this sprint; How will the chosen work get DONE?

front.title: Sprint Value
front.content: Why is this Sprint Valuable? (Sprint Goal)

back.title: PO proposes to increase value and utility
back.content: PO proposes how the product could increase its value and utility in the current Sprint. The whole scrum team collaborates to define a SPRINT GOAL that communicates why the Sprint is valuable to stakeholders. It must be finalised prior to the end of the Sprint Planning.

front.title: Definition of Done
front.content: What can be Done this Sprint?

back.title: Developers select items in product backlog
back.content: Through discussion with PO, development team selects items from the product backlog to include in current sprint. Scrum team will refine these items during this time; increases understanding and confidence. Use empirical knowledge to know capacity (and consider definition of done) for better forecast

front.title: Increment
front.content: How will the work get done?

back.title: For each PBI, plan Increment that meets Def of Done
back.content: Decompose PBI into smaller work items of one day or less. Done by development team who is responsible for turning PBI into increment of value. Sprint Goal, PBI, and plan for delivering them are considered the Sprint Backlog. Timeboxed to eight hours for one month sprint, shorter for shorter sprints

front.title: Daily Scrum
front.content: What is the Daily Scrum?

back.title: Inspect and Adapt
back.content: Purpose is the inspect progress towards Sprint goal, and adapt sprint backlog as necessary. 15 minutes for the development team; held at same time and place. If PO / SM actively working on items they attend as development team.

front.title: Purpose of Daily Scrum
front.content: What is the Purpose of the Daily Scrum

back.title: Focus on progress toward Sprint Goal
back.content: Development team can use whatever structure for the scrum; however it must focus on progress toward Sprint goal and actionable plan for the next day of work. Creates focus and improves self management.

front.title: Adjustments and Purpose
front.content: How is daily scrum adjusted?

back.title: Dev Team can meet throughout the day
back.content: Daily Scrums improve comms, identify impediments, promote quick decision making (reduces need for meetings). Its not the only time developers can adjust their plan. They often meet throughout the day for detailed discussions adapting/replanning the rest of the Sprint's work

front.title: Sprint Review
front.content: What is the Sprint review

back.title: Inspect outcomes of sprint and adapt
back.content: Scrum Team presents results and progress toward the product goal is discussed. Review allows for inspection of the outcomes of the sprint and to determine future adaptions.

front.title: Components of Sprint Review
front.content: What are the components of a sprint review?

back.title: Review, discuss, adjust backlog
back.content: Review what was accomplished in the sprint and what has changed. Collaborate on what to do next. Product Backlog adjusted (to meet new opportunities). Sprint review is working session and should avoid being a presentation. It is timeboxed to a maximum of four hours for 1 month sprint. Shorter for shorter sprints

front.title: Sprint Retrospective
front.content: What is a Sprint Retrospective?

back.title: Plan ways to increase quality and effectiveness
back.content: Scrum Team inspects how last sprint went based on individuals, interactions, tools, and definition of done. Assumptions that led team astray and origin explored. Discuss what went well, problems, and how they were solved. What to try next time (can be added to sprint backlog next sprint). Retro concludes sprint.

front.title: Sprint Retro Timebox
front.content: What is the max amount of time for a Sprint Retrospective?

back.title: 3 hours for 1 month sprint
back.content: For shorter sprints, the event is usually shorter.

front.title: Scrum Artifacts
front.content: What are scrum artifacts?

back.title: Represents work or value
back.content: Artifacts are designed to maximise transparency of key information; everyone inspecting them has the same basis for adaption. Each has commitment to ensure it provides information that enhances transparency and focus against which progress can be measured

front.title: Product Backlog
front.content: What is the product backlog?

back.title: Product backlog measures progress of product goal
back.content: Emergent ordered list of what needs to be improved on product. Single source of work by scrum team.

front.title: Product Backlog Refinement
front.content: What is Product Backlog Refinement?

front.title: PBI Sizing
front.content: Who is responsible for PBI Sizing?

back.title: Developer working on the item
back.content: PO may influence developers by helping them understand and select trade-offs

front.title: Product Goals
front.content: What is a Product Goal?

back.title: Describes future state of the Product
back.content: It serves as a target for the scrum team to plan against. A product goal is in the product backlog. The rest of the product backlog emerges to define what will fulfil this goal. Product Goal is a long-term objective for the SCRUM TEAM.

front.title: Product
front.content: What is a Product?

back.title: A vehicle to Deliver Value
back.content: Clear boundaries, known stakeholders, well-defined users/customers. Can be a product, service, or something more abstract

front.title: Sprint Backlog
front.content: What is a Sprint Backlog?

back.title: Sprint backlog measures progress of sprint goal
back.content: Comprised of a Sprint Goal (why), the PBI selected for the sprint (what), and actionable plan for delivering the Increment (how). It is a plan by and for development team. Highly visible, real-time picture of work the devs plan to accomplish during the sprint in order to achieve the Sprint Goal

front.title: Sprint Backlog items
front.content: What should be in the Sprint Backlog?

back.title: Sprint Goal, PBI, and Increment plan
back.content: The Sprint backlog is updated throughout the sprint as more is learned. It should have enough detail that they can inspect their progress in the Daily Scrum

front.title: Sprint Goals
front.content: What is a Sprint Goal?

back.title: Single Objective for the Sprint
back.content: Sprint Goal is a COMMITMENT made by the developers; it provides flexibility in terms of the exact work needed to achieve it. Creates coherence and focus, encouraging Scrum Team to work together.

front.title: Sprint Goal Creation
front.content: When is the Sprint Goal Created?

back.title: During Sprint Planning EVENT
back.content: Created during Sprint Planning and added to the Sprint Backlog. As the developers work during the sprint they keep the Sprint Goal in mind. If the work turns out to be different, they collaborate with the Product Owner to nego scope of the Sprint Backlog without impacting Sprint Goal

front.title: Increment
front.content: What is an Increment?

back.title: Increment measures progress of definition of done
back.content: A concrete stepping stone TOWARDS the Product Goal. Each Increment is additive to prior increments and thoroughly VERIFIED to ensure they work together. To provide value, each Increment MUST BE USEABLE

front.title: Increment within Sprint
front.content: How many increments in a Sprint?

back.title: As many as required
back.content: Multiple Increments can be created. The Sum of the Increments are presented in the Sprint Review. Increment may be delivered to stakeholders PRIOR to end of sprint. Sprint review is not to be considered a GATE to releasing value

front.title: Work is done
front.content: When is work considered part of an Increment?

back.title: When it meets definition of done
back.content: Work cannot be considered part of the increment unless it meets the definition of done

front.title: Definition of Done
front.content: What is the Definition of Done?

back.title: Formal description of increment that can be released
back.content: An increment can be released when it meets the quality measures required for the product. When a PBI meets a Def of Done, an Increment is created.

front.title: Transparency and Def of Done
front.content: How does Def of Done create Transparency?

back.title: Provides everyone understanding of work completed
back.content: It provides everyone a shared understanding of what work was done as part of the Increment. If a PBI does not meet Def of Done, it cannot be released / presented at Sprint Review. It returns to the Product backlog for future consideration

front.title: Multiple Scrum Teams and Def of Done
front.content: How does Definition of Done related to multiple scrum teams working on the same product?

back.title: Must mutually define and comply with same Def of Done
back.content: Developers are required to conform to Definition of Done. If there are multiple Scrum Teams working together on a single product; they must mutually define and comply with the same Def of Done

front.title: Def of Done and Standards
front.content: What happens if Def of Done is part of Org standards?

back.title: All Scrum Teams must follow it (at a Minimum)
back.content: If def of done for an increment is part of the standards of an organisation, all scrum teams must follow it (as a minimum). If not a standard, Scrum Team must create a Definition of Done appropriate for the product
